## GAD-7 vs SAS

GAD-7 vs SAS: A Comparison Comparing assessment tools like the Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7) and the Social Aptitute Scale (SAS) can be a hefty task for researchers. The nuanced language and specific context of each questionnaire item requires great attention to detail. However, this is where Harmony comes in. GAD-7 vs SAS comparisons become significantly simpler using this breakthrough software tool. Harmony uses natural language processing and generative AI models to harmonise and compare items from different psychological instruments, even if they're in different languages. The GAD-7 vs SAS comparison, for instance, can be done more efficiently and accurately. Harmony compares each item in these instruments and provides a match percentage to help simplify comparisons. No longer do you have to manually parse through lengthy PDFs and transfer data to Excel. With Harmony, you can either select from its extensive database or upload your own instruments in PDF format via its user-friendly interface available at https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app. Make GAD-7 vs SAS comparison easier, more effective, and more harmonised with Harmony.

## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
